predictions.headline: Should You Buy Stock in the Largest Company in the World?
predictions.content:
The world's biggest companies have proved themselves over time, generating earnings growth and stock performance. They've built rock-solid businesses, demonstrated they can prevail even in competitive industries, and generally these points should set them up for future success too. And, according to Motley Fool research, all but one of these companies has delivered five-year annualized returns in the double digits. So investors who have bought these players and held on for the long term have scored a win.

Today, about half of the 20 largest companies are in the technology field, specializing in everything from artificial intelligence (AI) chips to social media and smartphones. And speaking of smartphones, the company that tops the list as the biggest by market value is iPhone maker Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL). The tech giant was worth $3.68 trillion as of Jan. 6, a step ahead of the $3.54 trillion Nvidia. And Apple also is the first company ever to reach market cap levels of $1 trillion, $2 trillion, and $3 trillion.

Founded in 1976, Apple has come a long way, building a consumer electronics and services empire that generates billions of dollars in earnings annually -- and the stock has soared more than 184,000% since its market debut in 1980. Now the question is: Should you buy stock in Apple, or is it too late to get in on this market powerhouse? Let's find out.Image source: Getty Images.

A strong competitive advantage

So, first, a little bit of background on Apple. I probably don't have to tell you that the company is maker of some of today's best-known consumer products, from the iPhone as I mentioned, to the Mac and iPad. What's kept Apple ahead is its innovation and ability to keep users loyal to its products -- they'll wait for the latest iPhone release, for example, and won't opt for lower-priced rivals. This moat, or competitive advantage, has played a key role in Apple's earnings growth over time.

Apple's gross profit on a trailing-12-month basis totals more than $180 billion, and revenue tops $390 billion.AAPL Gross Profit (TTM) data by YCharts

And thanks to the company's earnings strength, the stock has delivered a five-year annualized return of more than 27%. Last year, Apple rose 30% as tech companies drove gains in all three major benchmarks: the Nasdaq, the S&P 500, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

Since Apple has been around for so long, you may wonder if its biggest phases of growth are in the past. It's true that this company probably won't deliver the same growth you'll find in a younger player that's just starting to build its business or a company like Nvidia that's at the heart of the high-growth AI revolution. But the dominance Apple has built in its market over time as well as it's own expansion into AI could power a new phase of growth ahead.

Story Continues

A significant new opportunity

Apple now has an installed base of more than 2.2 billion products worldwide, and that has paved the pathway to a new, massive opportunity: services revenue. The company offers users of its products a variety of them, from digital content to cloud storage. And that has led to record services revenue quarter after quarter in recent times.

On top of that, the company has launched its AI offering, Apple Intelligence, and is integrating it into its products. That should reinforce the loyalty of fans, bringing them an even more powerful experience across devices.

So now let's get back to our question: Should you buy stock in the world's largest company? This depends on your investment strategy. If you're an aggressive investor looking for enormous growth, you may find better opportunities elsewhere. But for most other investors, Apple today still makes a compelling buy as the company has a strong moat to ensure its market leadership -- and services and AI should add to growth moving forward. All of this means the stock has room to run and could help you score an investing win over the long haul.

Should you invest $1,000 in Apple right now?

Before you buy stock in Apple, consider this:

The Motley Fool Stock Advisor analyst team just identified what they believe are the 10 best stocks for investors to buy now… and Apple wasn’t one of them. The 10 stocks that made the cut could produce monster returns in the coming years.

Consider when Nvidia made this list on April 15, 2005... if you invested $1,000 at the time of our recommendation, you’d have $832,928!*

predictions.headline: Apple's 'Made in America' Chips: TSMC Arizona Fab Set to Launch Q1 2025
predictions.content:
Following the report on Tuesday, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSM, Financial) will start supplying semiconductors to Apple (AAPL, Financial) in Q1 2025, and it will stay set to begin using the semiconductors manufactured at the Arizona fab. Those processors are being quality verified in the batch of initial processors to be sure they're providing the same quality as TSMC's highest-end chips coming out of Taiwan, Nikkei Asia said. Apple's first major customer for the fab is expected to begin mass production as early as Q1 2025 if testing does not experience any setbacks.

It is a big step forward for the United States on its journey toward semiconductor independence by cutting reliance on Taiwan a region susceptible to geopolitical tensions with Beijing and natural disaster risks. The Arizona fab is a key move to strengthen U.S. semiconductor supply chains as competition in the industry heats up globally.

The Arizona facility has led the transition, but other tech giants, such as AMD (AMD, Financial) and Nvidia (NVDA, Financial), are doing test production there, indicating a possible use of locally produced chips. For now, chips manufactured in Arizona are being shipped back to Amkor in Taiwan for packaging until a new facility in Peoria, Arizona, is complete.

LCY Chemical, a supplier now aligned close to an Arizona fab, which had its deployment delayed by about a year due to logistical challenges, is one of those. However, the project highlights the U.S. semiconductor industry's new tide of reshoring critical manufacturing capabilities despite these hurdles.

This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

View Comments
predictions.reasoning: The news about Apple's partnership with TSMC to produce chips in Arizona is a significant development that aligns with the trend of reshoring semiconductor manufacturing in the U.S. This move is likely to enhance Apple's supply chain resilience and reduce geopolitical risks associated with reliance on Taiwan. The announcement of mass production starting in Q1 2025 indicates a long-term positive outlook for Apple's operational capabilities. Given these factors, the probability of the stock price rising is higher than that of it falling, as investors may view this as a strategic advantage for Apple in the competitive tech landscape.

predictions.headline: Apple's 'Made in America' Chips: TSMC Arizona Fab Set to Launch Q1 2025
predictions.content:
Following the report on Tuesday, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSM, Financial) will start supplying semiconductors to Apple (AAPL, Financial) in Q1 2025, and it will stay set to begin using the semiconductors manufactured at the Arizona fab. Those processors are being quality verified in the batch of initial processors to be sure they're providing the same quality as TSMC's highest-end chips coming out of Taiwan, Nikkei Asia said. Apple's first major customer for the fab is expected to begin mass production as early as Q1 2025 if testing does not experience any setbacks.

It is a big step forward for the United States on its journey toward semiconductor independence by cutting reliance on Taiwan a region susceptible to geopolitical tensions with Beijing and natural disaster risks. The Arizona fab is a key move to strengthen U.S. semiconductor supply chains as competition in the industry heats up globally.

The Arizona facility has led the transition, but other tech giants, such as AMD (AMD, Financial) and Nvidia (NVDA, Financial), are doing test production there, indicating a possible use of locally produced chips. For now, chips manufactured in Arizona are being shipped back to Amkor in Taiwan for packaging until a new facility in Peoria, Arizona, is complete.

LCY Chemical, a supplier now aligned close to an Arizona fab, which had its deployment delayed by about a year due to logistical challenges, is one of those. However, the project highlights the U.S. semiconductor industry's new tide of reshoring critical manufacturing capabilities despite these hurdles.

This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

predictions.reasoning: The news about Apple's partnership with TSMC to produce chips in Arizona is a significant development that enhances Apple's supply chain resilience and reduces geopolitical risks associated with reliance on Taiwan. This move aligns with the trend of reshoring semiconductor manufacturing in the U.S., which is generally viewed positively by investors. However, there are mixed signals from analysts regarding Apple's overall outlook, with some highlighting challenges such as competition and product cycle concerns. predictions.headline: Apple's 'Made in America' Chips: TSMC Arizona Fab Set to Launch Q1 2025
predictions.content:
Following the report on Tuesday, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSM, Financial) will start supplying semiconductors to Apple (AAPL, Financial) in Q1 2025, and it will stay set to begin using the semiconductors manufactured at the Arizona fab. Those processors are being quality verified in the batch of initial processors to be sure they're providing the same quality as TSMC's highest-end chips coming out of Taiwan, Nikkei Asia said. Apple's first major customer for the fab is expected to begin mass production as early as Q1 2025 if testing does not experience any setbacks.

It is a big step forward for the United States on its journey toward semiconductor independence by cutting reliance on Taiwan a region susceptible to geopolitical tensions with Beijing and natural disaster risks. The Arizona fab is a key move to strengthen U.S. semiconductor supply chains as competition in the industry heats up globally.

The Arizona facility has led the transition, but other tech giants, such as AMD (AMD, Financial) and Nvidia (NVDA, Financial), are doing test production there, indicating a possible use of locally produced chips. For now, chips manufactured in Arizona are being shipped back to Amkor in Taiwan for packaging until a new facility in Peoria, Arizona, is complete.

LCY Chemical, a supplier now aligned close to an Arizona fab, which had its deployment delayed by about a year due to logistical challenges, is one of those. However, the project highlights the U.S. semiconductor industry's new tide of reshoring critical manufacturing capabilities despite these hurdles.

This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

View Comments
predictions.reasoning: The news about Apple's partnership with TSMC to produce chips in Arizona is a significant development that enhances Apple's supply chain resilience and reduces geopolitical risks associated with reliance on Taiwan. This move aligns with the trend of reshoring semiconductor manufacturing in the U.S., which is generally viewed positively by investors. However, there are mixed signals from analysts regarding Apple's overall outlook, with some highlighting challenges such as competition and product cycle concerns. Balancing these factors, I estimate a higher probability of the stock price rising due to the strategic importance of the Arizona fab and its potential long-term benefits for Apple, despite some analysts maintaining a cautious stance.

predictions.headline: Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint
predictions.content:
Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint

Smartphone giantApple Inc’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhones, minus their highly anticipated Apple Intelligence features, failed to gain traction in China, paving the way for the country’s domestic players in 2024.

Counterpoint’s Tarun Pathak mentioned 2024 as a year of recovery and normalization after a difficult 2023.

Global smartphone sales grew 4% in 2024 after two consecutive years of annual declines, Counterpoint cites preliminary data. Smartphone sales marked a decade low in 2023.

Also Read: Nvidia, Broadcom Among Goldman Highlights For AI Opportunities

Almost every market grew, led by Europe, China, and Latin America.

The iPhone captured an 18% market share in 2024, down from 19% in 2023.

However, Apple continued to grow in its non-core markets, like Latin America, Africa, and Asia-Pacific. Needham’s Laura Martin expects iPhones to account for 89%-96% of Apple’s fiscal 2025 revenue.

Counterpoint’s Ivan Lam flagged a consumer pivot to Apple’s premium offering, helping to offset some of the declines. Lam pointed to the growing sell-through share of Pro series devices in markets like China.

Samsung Electronics Co (OTC:SSNLF) led with a market share of 19% in 2024, down from 20% in 2023, backed by demand for its S24 series and A-series product lines. The S24 series gained traction as the first phone positioned as an AI device and performed exceptionally in Western Europe and the USA.

Xiaomi (OTC:XIACF) (OTC:XIACY) reported a 14% market share in 2024, up from 13% a year ago. Oppo and Vivo each captured an 8% market share in 2024.

Xiaomi grew fastest among the top five brands in 2024, backed by its premiumization and expansion activities.

Oppo ended the year with stronger momentum. Vivo emerged amongst the top five, led by strong performance in India and China.

The top five remained the same as in 2023 but lost some share to Huawei Technologies, Honor, and Motorola. Huawei has no plans to give any respite to its rivals, who are doling out discounts for the New Year on their premium models.

China targets expanding government-supported consumption subsidies to include smartphones and other electronics, which will likely benefit domestic brands like Huawei and Xiaomi.

While generative AI-capable smartphones remain limited to the premium segment, Counterpoint expects them to become a norm for mid-range devices. By 2028, Counterpoint expects nine out of ten smartphones priced above $250 to be Generative AI-capable.

In 2025, Counterpoint expects revenue growth to continue to outpace volume growth, with revenues growing 8%, compared to 4%.

Story Continues

Price Action: AAPL stock is down 0.54% at $230.83 at the last check on Monday.

Also Read:

Nvidia’s AI Leadership Shines While ON Semiconductor Faces Demand Slump: Analyst

Photo courtesy: Apple

This could negatively impact investor sentiment due to concerns over revenue growth and market dominance. However, Apple is showing growth in non-core markets and has a strong premium segment, which may offset some of the declines. The overall sentiment is mixed but leans slightly negative due to the loss in a key market. The stock was already down 0.54% at the time of the news, reflecting initial market reaction.

.With the popular A-series portfolio and significant demand for its AI-oriented S24 series, Samsung maintains leadership. In Europe and the United States, the S24 series excels especially, reinforcing Samsung's position.Apple's iPhone 16 series gets mixed reviews, mainly related to Apple Intelligence feature delays. Apple does, however, find expansion in areas such Asia, Africa, and Latin America.

Demand for the Pro and Pro Max variants keeps rising in China; Q4 2024 sales might even reach 50%.Reversing a decade-low in 2023, global smartphone sales climb 4% in 2024. Globally, consumer sentiment is improving; in Europe, China, and Latin America especially, it is showing a healthy improvement.

Apple is providing discounts on iPhone 16 models in China in order to keep its hold in a very cutthroat market while challenging Huawei.

This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

The iPhone captured an 18% market share in 2024, down from 19% in 2023.

However, Apple continued to grow in its non-core markets, like Latin America, Africa, and Asia-Pacific. Needham’s Laura Martin expects iPhones to account for 89%-96% of Apple’s fiscal 2025 revenue.

Counterpoint’s Ivan Lam flagged a consumer pivot to Apple’s premium offering, helping to offset some of the declines. Lam pointed to the growing sell-through share of Pro series devices in markets like China.

Samsung Electronics Co (OTC:SSNLF) led with a market share of 19% in 2024, down from 20% in 2023, backed by demand for its S24 series and A-series product lines. The S24 series gained traction as the first phone positioned as an AI device and performed exceptionally in Western Europe and the USA.

Xiaomi (OTC:XIACF) (OTC:XIACY) reported a 14% market share in 2024, up from 13% a year ago. Oppo and Vivo each captured an 8% market share in 2024.

Xiaomi grew fastest among the top five brands in 2024, backed by its premiumization and expansion activities.

Oppo ended the year with stronger momentum. Vivo emerged amongst the top five, led by strong performance in India and China.

The top five remained the same as in 2023 but lost some share to Huawei Technologies, Honor, and Motorola. Huawei has no plans to give any respite to its rivals, who are doling out discounts for the New Year on their premium models.

China targets expanding government-supported consumption subsidies to include smartphones and other electronics, which will likely benefit domestic brands like Huawei and Xiaomi.

While generative AI-capable smartphones remain limited to the premium segment, Counterpoint expects them to become a norm for mid-range devices. By 2028, Counterpoint expects nine out of ten smartphones priced above $250 to be Generative AI-capable.

In 2025, Counterpoint expects revenue growth to continue to outpace volume growth, with revenues growing 8%, compared to 4%.

Global smartphone sales grew 4% in 2024 after two consecutive years of annual declines, Counterpoint cites preliminary data. Smartphone sales marked a decade low in 2023.

Also Read: Nvidia, Broadcom Among Goldman Highlights For AI Opportunities

Almost every market grew, led by Europe, China, and Latin America.

The iPhone captured an 18% market share in 2024, down from 19% in 2023.

However, Apple continued to grow in its non-core markets, like Latin America, Africa, and Asia-Pacific. Needham’s Laura Martin expects iPhones to account for 89%-96% of Apple’s fiscal 2025 revenue.

Counterpoint’s Ivan Lam flagged a consumer pivot to Apple’s premium offering, helping to offset some of the declines. Lam pointed to the growing sell-through share of Pro series devices in markets like China.

Samsung Electronics Co (OTC:SSNLF) led with a market share of 19% in 2024, down from 20% in 2023, backed by demand for its S24 series and A-series product lines. The S24 series gained traction as the first phone positioned as an AI device and performed exceptionally in Western Europe and the USA.

Xiaomi (OTC:XIACF) (OTC:XIACY) reported a 14% market share in 2024, up from 13% a year ago. Oppo and Vivo each captured an 8% market share in 2024.

Xiaomi grew fastest among the top five brands in 2024, backed by its premiumization and expansion activities.

Oppo ended the year with stronger momentum. Vivo emerged amongst the top five, led by strong performance in India and China.

The top five remained the same as in 2023 but lost some share to Huawei Technologies, Honor, and Motorola. Huawei has no plans to give any respite to its rivals, who are doling out discounts for the New Year on their premium models.

China targets expanding government-supported consumption subsidies to include smartphones and other electronics, which will likely benefit domestic brands like Huawei and Xiaomi.

While generative AI-capable smartphones remain limited to the premium segment, Counterpoint expects them to become a norm for mid-range devices. By 2028, Counterpoint expects nine out of ten smartphones priced above $250 to be Generative AI-capable.

In 2025, Counterpoint expects revenue growth to continue to outpace volume growth, with revenues growing 8%, compared to 4%.

predictions.headline: Broadcom's AI Boom: Citi Sets $220 Target as Revenue and Dividends Soar
predictions.content:
Broadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO) just dropped the kind of news that makes investors sit up and take notice. While U.S. export restrictions on AI chips to China might rattle others, Broadcom is shrugging it off. Citi analysts note potential risks tied to Bytedance, a key customer projected to bring in $2$3 billion in 2025 sales. But here's the kicker: AI-heavyweights like Google (GOOGL) and Meta (NASDAQ:META) are set to pump $10 billion into Broadcom's ASIC sales next year. Throw in booming demand from new powerhouses like OpenAI and Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), and you've got a recipe for growth that dwarfs any headwinds.

High Yield Dividend Stocks in Gurus' Portfolio This Powerful Chart Made Peter Lynch 29% A Year For 13 Years How to calculate the intrinsic value of a stock?

Let's talk numbers, because Broadcom's fiscal 2024 results are jaw-dropping. Revenue soared 44% to a record $51.6 billion, with AI leading the chargea staggering 220% jump in AI revenue to $12.2 billion. Its semiconductor and infrastructure software segments smashed expectations, delivering $30.1 billion and $21.5 billion, respectively. The cherry on top? An 11% quarterly dividend hike to $0.59 per share, marking the 14th consecutive annual increase. Oh, and the company's free cash flow? A whopping $19.4 billion, positioning Broadcom to keep rewarding investors while powering ahead.

Looking forward, Broadcom is brimming with confidence, forecasting a 22% revenue jump in Q1 FY25 to $14.6 billion. Citi remains bullish, slapping a Buy rating and a $220 price target on the stock. Broadcom isn't just riding the AI waveit's building the surfboard, the wave, and the entire beach. If you're looking for a leader in tech that knows how to navigate challenges and crush expectations, Broadcom's got your attention.

This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

View Comments
predictions.reasoning: The news highlights Broadcom's impressive financial performance and growth prospects, particularly in the AI sector, which is likely to positively influence investor sentiment. Although the news primarily focuses on Broadcom, it indirectly benefits Apple due to its involvement in AI and semiconductor demand. The bullish outlook from Citi with a $220 price target for Broadcom suggests a strong market confidence that could spill over to Apple. Given the positive sentiment surrounding AI and tech stocks, I estimate a higher probability of AAPL's stock price rising rather than falling.

predictions.headline: Broadcom's AI Boom: Citi Sets $220 Target as Revenue and Dividends Soar
predictions.content:
Broadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO) just dropped the kind of news that makes investors sit up and take notice. While U.S. export restrictions on AI chips to China might rattle others, Broadcom is shrugging it off. Citi analysts note potential risks tied to Bytedance, a key customer projected to bring in $2$3 billion in 2025 sales. But here's the kicker: AI-heavyweights like Google (GOOGL) and Meta (NASDAQ:META) are set to pump $10 billion into Broadcom's ASIC sales next year. Throw in booming demand from new powerhouses like OpenAI and Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), and you've got a recipe for growth that dwarfs any headwinds.

High Yield Dividend Stocks in Gurus' Portfolio This Powerful Chart Made Peter Lynch 29% A Year For 13 Years How to calculate the intrinsic value of a stock?

Let's talk numbers, because Broadcom's fiscal 2024 results are jaw-dropping. Revenue soared 44% to a record $51.6 billion, with AI leading the chargea staggering 220% jump in AI revenue to $12.2 billion. Its semiconductor and infrastructure software segments smashed expectations, delivering $30.1 billion and $21.5 billion, respectively. The cherry on top? An 11% quarterly dividend hike to $0.59 per share, marking the 14th consecutive annual increase. Oh, and the company's free cash flow? A whopping $19.4 billion, positioning Broadcom to keep rewarding investors while powering ahead.

Looking forward, Broadcom is brimming with confidence, forecasting a 22% revenue jump in Q1 FY25 to $14.6 billion. Citi remains bullish, slapping a Buy rating and a $220 price target on the stock. Broadcom isn't just riding the AI waveit's building the surfboard, the wave, and the entire beach. If you're looking for a leader in tech that knows how to navigate challenges and crush expectations, Broadcom's got your attention.

predictions.headline: Apple Falls to Second Place Globally as Samsung's S24 Dominates Smartphone Market
predictions.content:
Following Samsung (SSNLF), Counterpoint Research notes Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) now ranks second in worldwide smartphone market share for 2024. Apple commands a 18%, down from 19% last year; Samsung keeps 19%, a little decline from 20% in 2023

.With the popular A-series portfolio and significant demand for its AI-oriented S24 series, Samsung maintains leadership. In Europe and the United States, the S24 series excels especially, reinforcing Samsung's position.Apple's iPhone 16 series gets mixed reviews, mainly related to Apple Intelligence feature delays. Apple does, however, find expansion in areas such Asia, Africa, and Latin America.

Demand for the Pro and Pro Max variants keeps rising in China; Q4 2024 sales might even reach 50%.Reversing a decade-low in 2023, global smartphone sales climb 4% in 2024. Globally, consumer sentiment is improving; in Europe, China, and Latin America especially, it is showing a healthy improvement.

Apple is providing discounts on iPhone 16 models in China in order to keep its hold in a very cutthroat market while challenging Huawei.

This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

View Comments
predictions.reasoning: The news presents a mixed picture for Apple.  Losing the top spot in global smartphone market share to Samsung is a significant negative, especially given Samsung's success with its S24 series.  The need for Apple to discount iPhones in China to compete with Huawei further suggests competitive pressure and potential margin erosion. Delays in the Apple Intelligence feature also represent a setback. However, several mitigating factors exist. Global smartphone sales are growing, and Apple is expanding in emerging markets. Strong sales of Pro models in China are positive.  The previous predictions show a wide range of opinions, reflecting the complexity of the situation.  While the loss of market share and competitive pressures are substantial negatives, the growth in other regions and the strong performance of the Pro models suggest that the impact might be less severe than a simple market share loss would indicate. Considering the mixed nature of the news and the previous predictions, I'm assigning a slightly higher probability to a price fall, reflecting the loss of market share and competitive pressures, but acknowledging the potential for the positive aspects to mitigate the negative impact.  The previous rounds' predictions show a trend towards a higher probability of a price rise, but I believe the current news warrants a more cautious outlook.

predictions.headline: Broadcom's AI Boom: Citi Sets $220 Target as Revenue and Dividends Soar
predictions.content:
Broadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO) just dropped the kind of news that makes investors sit up and take notice. While U.S. export restrictions on AI chips to China might rattle others, Broadcom is shrugging it off. Citi analysts note potential risks tied to Bytedance, a key customer projected to bring in $2$3 billion in 2025 sales. But here's the kicker: AI-heavyweights like Google (GOOGL) and Meta (NASDAQ:META) are set to pump $10 billion into Broadcom's ASIC sales next year. Throw in booming demand from new powerhouses like OpenAI and Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), and you've got a recipe for growth that dwarfs any headwinds.

High Yield Dividend Stocks in Gurus' Portfolio This Powerful Chart Made Peter Lynch 29% A Year For 13 Years How to calculate the intrinsic value of a stock?

Let's talk numbers, because Broadcom's fiscal 2024 results are jaw-dropping. Revenue soared 44% to a record $51.6 billion, with AI leading the chargea staggering 220% jump in AI revenue to $12.2 billion. Its semiconductor and infrastructure software segments smashed expectations, delivering $30.1 billion and $21.5 billion, respectively. The cherry on top? An 11% quarterly dividend hike to $0.59 per share, marking the 14th consecutive annual increase. Oh, and the company's free cash flow? A whopping $19.4 billion, positioning Broadcom to keep rewarding investors while powering ahead.

Looking forward, Broadcom is brimming with confidence, forecasting a 22% revenue jump in Q1 FY25 to $14.6 billion. Citi remains bullish, slapping a Buy rating and a $220 price target on the stock. Broadcom isn't just riding the AI waveit's building the surfboard, the wave, and the entire beach. If you're looking for a leader in tech that knows how to navigate challenges and crush expectations, Broadcom's got your attention.

This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

predictions.reasoning: The financial news highlights Broadcom's impressive financial performance and growth prospects in the AI sector, which is likely to have a positive spillover effect on Apple Inc. due to their shared involvement in AI and semiconductor technology. Citi's $220 target price for Broadcom indicates strong market confidence, reflecting positively on Apple. Additionally, the involvement of major tech companies such as Google and Meta in boosting Broadcom's AI-related business suggests a bullish outlook for the broader tech sector, including Apple. Given the recent trends in stock price predictions provided by different models, the majority predict a rise in stock prices, influenced by positive sentiments and strong financial forecasts.

predictions.headline: Apple Falls to Second Place Globally as Samsung's S24 Dominates Smartphone Market
predictions.content:
Following Samsung (SSNLF), Counterpoint Research notes Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) now ranks second in worldwide smartphone market share for 2024. Apple commands a 18%, down from 19% last year; Samsung keeps 19%, a little decline from 20% in 2023

.With the popular A-series portfolio and significant demand for its AI-oriented S24 series, Samsung maintains leadership. In Europe and the United States, the S24 series excels especially, reinforcing Samsung's position.Apple's iPhone 16 series gets mixed reviews, mainly related to Apple Intelligence feature delays. Apple does, however, find expansion in areas such Asia, Africa, and Latin America.

Demand for the Pro and Pro Max variants keeps rising in China; Q4 2024 sales might even reach 50%.Reversing a decade-low in 2023, global smartphone sales climb 4% in 2024. Globally, consumer sentiment is improving; in Europe, China, and Latin America especially, it is showing a healthy improvement.

Apple is providing discounts on iPhone 16 models in China in order to keep its hold in a very cutthroat market while challenging Huawei.

This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

predictions.reasoning: The news indicates that Apple has fallen to second place in global smartphone market share, which could negatively impact investor sentiment. Mixed reviews for the iPhone 16 series and the need for discounts in China further indicate potential challenges for Apple. However, there are positive signs such as rising demand for the Pro and Pro Max variants in China and overall improvement in global consumer sentiment. Given these mixed signals, the probability of the stock price falling is higher than that of it rising.

predictions.headline: Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint
predictions.content:
Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint

Smartphone giantApple Inc’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhones, minus their highly anticipated Apple Intelligence features, failed to gain traction in China, paving the way for the country’s domestic players in 2024.

Counterpoint’s Tarun Pathak mentioned 2024 as a year of recovery and normalization after a difficult 2023.

Global smartphone sales grew 4% in 2024 after two consecutive years of annual declines, Counterpoint cites preliminary data. Smartphone sales marked a decade low in 2023.

Also Read: Nvidia, Broadcom Among Goldman Highlights For AI Opportunities

Almost every market grew, led by Europe, China, and Latin America.

The iPhone captured an 18% market share in 2024, down from 19% in 2023.

However, Apple continued to grow in its non-core markets, like Latin America, Africa, and Asia-Pacific. Needham’s Laura Martin expects iPhones to account for 89%-96% of Apple’s fiscal 2025 revenue.

Counterpoint’s Ivan Lam flagged a consumer pivot to Apple’s premium offering, helping to offset some of the declines. Lam pointed to the growing sell-through share of Pro series devices in markets like China.

Samsung Electronics Co (OTC:SSNLF) led with a market share of 19% in 2024, down from 20% in 2023, backed by demand for its S24 series and A-series product lines. The S24 series gained traction as the first phone positioned as an AI device and performed exceptionally in Western Europe and the USA.

Xiaomi (OTC:XIACF) (OTC:XIACY) reported a 14% market share in 2024, up from 13% a year ago. Oppo and Vivo each captured an 8% market share in 2024.

Xiaomi grew fastest among the top five brands in 2024, backed by its premiumization and expansion activities.

Oppo ended the year with stronger momentum. Vivo emerged amongst the top five, led by strong performance in India and China.

The top five remained the same as in 2023 but lost some share to Huawei Technologies, Honor, and Motorola. Huawei has no plans to give any respite to its rivals, who are doling out discounts for the New Year on their premium models.

China targets expanding government-supported consumption subsidies to include smartphones and other electronics, which will likely benefit domestic brands like Huawei and Xiaomi.

While generative AI-capable smartphones remain limited to the premium segment, Counterpoint expects them to become a norm for mid-range devices. By 2028, Counterpoint expects nine out of ten smartphones priced above $250 to be Generative AI-capable.

In 2025, Counterpoint expects revenue growth to continue to outpace volume growth, with revenues growing 8%, compared to 4%.

Story Continues

Price Action: AAPL stock is down 0.54% at $230.83 at the last check on Monday.

Also Read:

Nvidia’s AI Leadership Shines While ON Semiconductor Faces Demand Slump: Analyst

Photo courtesy: Apple

Although Apple is experiencing growth in non-core markets, the overall decline in market share and the rise of competitors like Huawei and Xiaomi could negatively impact investor sentiment. The stock is already down slightly, reflecting some market reaction to this news. Given these factors, there is a higher probability of the stock price falling compared to rising.

predictions.headline: Broadcom's AI Boom: Citi Sets $220 Target as Revenue and Dividends Soar
predictions.content:
Broadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO) just dropped the kind of news that makes investors sit up and take notice. While U.S. export restrictions on AI chips to China might rattle others, Broadcom is shrugging it off. Citi analysts note potential risks tied to Bytedance, a key customer projected to bring in $2$3 billion in 2025 sales. But here's the kicker: AI-heavyweights like Google (GOOGL) and Meta (NASDAQ:META) are set to pump $10 billion into Broadcom's ASIC sales next year. Throw in booming demand from new powerhouses like OpenAI and Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), and you've got a recipe for growth that dwarfs any headwinds.

High Yield Dividend Stocks in Gurus' Portfolio This Powerful Chart Made Peter Lynch 29% A Year For 13 Years How to calculate the intrinsic value of a stock?

Let's talk numbers, because Broadcom's fiscal 2024 results are jaw-dropping. Revenue soared 44% to a record $51.6 billion, with AI leading the chargea staggering 220% jump in AI revenue to $12.2 billion. Its semiconductor and infrastructure software segments smashed expectations, delivering $30.1 billion and $21.5 billion, respectively. The cherry on top? An 11% quarterly dividend hike to $0.59 per share, marking the 14th consecutive annual increase. Oh, and the company's free cash flow? A whopping $19.4 billion, positioning Broadcom to keep rewarding investors while powering ahead.

Looking forward, Broadcom is brimming with confidence, forecasting a 22% revenue jump in Q1 FY25 to $14.6 billion. Citi remains bullish, slapping a Buy rating and a $220 price target on the stock. Broadcom isn't just riding the AI waveit's building the surfboard, the wave, and the entire beach. If you're looking for a leader in tech that knows how to navigate challenges and crush expectations, Broadcom's got your attention.

This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

View Comments
predictions.reasoning: The news focuses on Broadcom's (AVGO) strong performance and future prospects, driven by the AI boom. While the article mentions Apple (AAPL) as a source of growing demand for Broadcom's ASICs, it doesn't directly discuss Apple's financial performance or strategic direction. The positive news about Broadcom could indirectly benefit Apple, as it suggests strong demand for components used in Apple products. However, the impact is likely to be muted compared to news directly related to Apple's own products, services, or financial results. Therefore, the probability of a significant stock price movement for Apple based solely on this news is moderate. I am estimating a slightly higher probability of a rise due to the positive sentiment surrounding the AI sector and Apple's involvement in it, but the effect is indirect.

predictions.headline: Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint
predictions.content:
Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint

Smartphone giantApple Inc’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhones, minus their highly anticipated Apple Intelligence features, failed to gain traction in China, paving the way for the country’s domestic players in 2024.

Counterpoint’s Tarun Pathak mentioned 2024 as a year of recovery and normalization after a difficult 2023.

Global smartphone sales grew 4% in 2024 after two consecutive years of annual declines, Counterpoint cites preliminary data. Smartphone sales marked a decade low in 2023.

Also Read: Nvidia, Broadcom Among Goldman Highlights For AI Opportunities

Almost every market grew, led by Europe, China, and Latin America.

The iPhone captured an 18% market share in 2024, down from 19% in 2023.

However, Apple continued to grow in its non-core markets, like Latin America, Africa, and Asia-Pacific. Needham’s Laura Martin expects iPhones to account for 89%-96% of Apple’s fiscal 2025 revenue.

Counterpoint’s Ivan Lam flagged a consumer pivot to Apple’s premium offering, helping to offset some of the declines. Lam pointed to the growing sell-through share of Pro series devices in markets like China.

Samsung Electronics Co (OTC:SSNLF) led with a market share of 19% in 2024, down from 20% in 2023, backed by demand for its S24 series and A-series product lines. The S24 series gained traction as the first phone positioned as an AI device and performed exceptionally in Western Europe and the USA.

Xiaomi (OTC:XIACF) (OTC:XIACY) reported a 14% market share in 2024, up from 13% a year ago. Oppo and Vivo each captured an 8% market share in 2024.

Xiaomi grew fastest among the top five brands in 2024, backed by its premiumization and expansion activities.

Oppo ended the year with stronger momentum. Vivo emerged amongst the top five, led by strong performance in India and China.

The top five remained the same as in 2023 but lost some share to Huawei Technologies, Honor, and Motorola. Huawei has no plans to give any respite to its rivals, who are doling out discounts for the New Year on their premium models.

China targets expanding government-supported consumption subsidies to include smartphones and other electronics, which will likely benefit domestic brands like Huawei and Xiaomi.

While generative AI-capable smartphones remain limited to the premium segment, Counterpoint expects them to become a norm for mid-range devices. By 2028, Counterpoint expects nine out of ten smartphones priced above $250 to be Generative AI-capable.

In 2025, Counterpoint expects revenue growth to continue to outpace volume growth, with revenues growing 8%, compared to 4%.

Story Continues

Price Action: AAPL stock is down 0.54% at $230.83 at the last check on Monday.

Also Read:

Nvidia’s AI Leadership Shines While ON Semiconductor Faces Demand Slump: Analyst

The stock is already down slightly, reflecting some market reaction to this news. Given these factors, I estimate a higher probability of the stock price falling compared to rising.

predictions.headline: Broadcom's AI Boom: Citi Sets $220 Target as Revenue and Dividends Soar
predictions.content:
Broadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO) just dropped the kind of news that makes investors sit up and take notice. While U.S. export restrictions on AI chips to China might rattle others, Broadcom is shrugging it off. Citi analysts note potential risks tied to Bytedance, a key customer projected to bring in $2$3 billion in 2025 sales. But here's the kicker: AI-heavyweights like Google (GOOGL) and Meta (NASDAQ:META) are set to pump $10 billion into Broadcom's ASIC sales next year. Throw in booming demand from new powerhouses like OpenAI and Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), and you've got a recipe for growth that dwarfs any headwinds.

High Yield Dividend Stocks in Gurus' Portfolio This Powerful Chart Made Peter Lynch 29% A Year For 13 Years How to calculate the intrinsic value of a stock?

Let's talk numbers, because Broadcom's fiscal 2024 results are jaw-dropping. Revenue soared 44% to a record $51.6 billion, with AI leading the chargea staggering 220% jump in AI revenue to $12.2 billion. Its semiconductor and infrastructure software segments smashed expectations, delivering $30.1 billion and $21.5 billion, respectively. The cherry on top? An 11% quarterly dividend hike to $0.59 per share, marking the 14th consecutive annual increase. Oh, and the company's free cash flow? A whopping $19.4 billion, positioning Broadcom to keep rewarding investors while powering ahead.

Looking forward, Broadcom is brimming with confidence, forecasting a 22% revenue jump in Q1 FY25 to $14.6 billion. Citi remains bullish, slapping a Buy rating and a $220 price target on the stock. Broadcom isn't just riding the AI waveit's building the surfboard, the wave, and the entire beach. If you're looking for a leader in tech that knows how to navigate challenges and crush expectations, Broadcom's got your attention.

This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

Considering the previous rounds, there's a mixed sentiment, but the trend seems to be slightly shifting towards a more positive outlook. Therefore, the positive news from Broadcom may outweigh the negative news.

predictions.headline: Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint
predictions.content:
Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint

Smartphone giantApple Inc’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhones, minus their highly anticipated Apple Intelligence features, failed to gain traction in China, paving the way for the country’s domestic players in 2024.

Counterpoint’s Tarun Pathak mentioned 2024 as a year of recovery and normalization after a difficult 2023.

Global smartphone sales grew 4% in 2024 after two consecutive years of annual declines, Counterpoint cites preliminary data. Smartphone sales marked a decade low in 2023.

Also Read: Nvidia, Broadcom Among Goldman Highlights For AI Opportunities

Almost every market grew, led by Europe, China, and Latin America.

The iPhone captured an 18% market share in 2024, down from 19% in 2023.

However, Apple continued to grow in its non-core markets, like Latin America, Africa, and Asia-Pacific. Needham’s Laura Martin expects iPhones to account for 89%-96% of Apple’s fiscal 2025 revenue.

Counterpoint’s Ivan Lam flagged a consumer pivot to Apple’s premium offering, helping to offset some of the declines. Lam pointed to the growing sell-through share of Pro series devices in markets like China.

Samsung Electronics Co (OTC:SSNLF) led with a market share of 19% in 2024, down from 20% in 2023, backed by demand for its S24 series and A-series product lines. The S24 series gained traction as the first phone positioned as an AI device and performed exceptionally in Western Europe and the USA.

Xiaomi (OTC:XIACF) (OTC:XIACY) reported a 14% market share in 2024, up from 13% a year ago. Oppo and Vivo each captured an 8% market share in 2024.

Xiaomi grew fastest among the top five brands in 2024, backed by its premiumization and expansion activities.

Oppo ended the year with stronger momentum. Vivo emerged amongst the top five, led by strong performance in India and China.

The top five remained the same as in 2023 but lost some share to Huawei Technologies, Honor, and Motorola. Huawei has no plans to give any respite to its rivals, who are doling out discounts for the New Year on their premium models.

China targets expanding government-supported consumption subsidies to include smartphones and other electronics, which will likely benefit domestic brands like Huawei and Xiaomi.

While generative AI-capable smartphones remain limited to the premium segment, Counterpoint expects them to become a norm for mid-range devices. By 2028, Counterpoint expects nine out of ten smartphones priced above $250 to be Generative AI-capable.

In 2025, Counterpoint expects revenue growth to continue to outpace volume growth, with revenues growing 8%, compared to 4%.

Story Continues

Price Action: AAPL stock is down 0.54% at $230.83 at the last check on Monday.

Also Read:

Nvidia’s AI Leadership Shines While ON Semiconductor Faces Demand Slump: Analyst

predictions.headline: Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint
predictions.content:
Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint

Smartphone giantApple Inc’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhones, minus their highly anticipated Apple Intelligence features, failed to gain traction in China, paving the way for the country’s domestic players in 2024.

Counterpoint’s Tarun Pathak mentioned 2024 as a year of recovery and normalization after a difficult 2023.

Global smartphone sales grew 4% in 2024 after two consecutive years of annual declines, Counterpoint cites preliminary data. Smartphone sales marked a decade low in 2023.

Also Read: Nvidia, Broadcom Among Goldman Highlights For AI Opportunities

Almost every market grew, led by Europe, China, and Latin America.

The iPhone captured an 18% market share in 2024, down from 19% in 2023.

However, Apple continued to grow in its non-core markets, like Latin America, Africa, and Asia-Pacific. Needham’s Laura Martin expects iPhones to account for 89%-96% of Apple’s fiscal 2025 revenue.

Counterpoint’s Ivan Lam flagged a consumer pivot to Apple’s premium offering, helping to offset some of the declines. Lam pointed to the growing sell-through share of Pro series devices in markets like China.

Samsung Electronics Co (OTC:SSNLF) led with a market share of 19% in 2024, down from 20% in 2023, backed by demand for its S24 series and A-series product lines. The S24 series gained traction as the first phone positioned as an AI device and performed exceptionally in Western Europe and the USA.

Xiaomi (OTC:XIACF) (OTC:XIACY) reported a 14% market share in 2024, up from 13% a year ago. Oppo and Vivo each captured an 8% market share in 2024.

Xiaomi grew fastest among the top five brands in 2024, backed by its premiumization and expansion activities.

Oppo ended the year with stronger momentum. Vivo emerged amongst the top five, led by strong performance in India and China.

The top five remained the same as in 2023 but lost some share to Huawei Technologies, Honor, and Motorola. Huawei has no plans to give any respite to its rivals, who are doling out discounts for the New Year on their premium models.

China targets expanding government-supported consumption subsidies to include smartphones and other electronics, which will likely benefit domestic brands like Huawei and Xiaomi.

While generative AI-capable smartphones remain limited to the premium segment, Counterpoint expects them to become a norm for mid-range devices. By 2028, Counterpoint expects nine out of ten smartphones priced above $250 to be Generative AI-capable.

In 2025, Counterpoint expects revenue growth to continue to outpace volume growth, with revenues growing 8%, compared to 4%.

Story Continues

Price Action: AAPL stock is down 0.54% at $230.83 at the last check on Monday.

Also Read:

Nvidia’s AI Leadership Shines While ON Semiconductor Faces Demand Slump: Analyst

predictions.headline: Broadcom's AI Boom: Citi Sets $220 Target as Revenue and Dividends Soar
predictions.content:
Broadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO) just dropped the kind of news that makes investors sit up and take notice. While U.S. export restrictions on AI chips to China might rattle others, Broadcom is shrugging it off. Citi analysts note potential risks tied to Bytedance, a key customer projected to bring in $2$3 billion in 2025 sales. But here's the kicker: AI-heavyweights like Google (GOOGL) and Meta (NASDAQ:META) are set to pump $10 billion into Broadcom's ASIC sales next year. Throw in booming demand from new powerhouses like OpenAI and Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), and you've got a recipe for growth that dwarfs any headwinds.

High Yield Dividend Stocks in Gurus' Portfolio This Powerful Chart Made Peter Lynch 29% A Year For 13 Years How to calculate the intrinsic value of a stock?

Let's talk numbers, because Broadcom's fiscal 2024 results are jaw-dropping. Revenue soared 44% to a record $51.6 billion, with AI leading the chargea staggering 220% jump in AI revenue to $12.2 billion. Its semiconductor and infrastructure software segments smashed expectations, delivering $30.1 billion and $21.5 billion, respectively. The cherry on top? An 11% quarterly dividend hike to $0.59 per share, marking the 14th consecutive annual increase. Oh, and the company's free cash flow? A whopping $19.4 billion, positioning Broadcom to keep rewarding investors while powering ahead.

Looking forward, Broadcom is brimming with confidence, forecasting a 22% revenue jump in Q1 FY25 to $14.6 billion. Citi remains bullish, slapping a Buy rating and a $220 price target on the stock. Broadcom isn't just riding the AI waveit's building the surfboard, the wave, and the entire beach. If you're looking for a leader in tech that knows how to navigate challenges and crush expectations, Broadcom's got your attention.

This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

predictions.headline: Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint
predictions.content:
Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint

Smartphone giantApple Inc’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhones, minus their highly anticipated Apple Intelligence features, failed to gain traction in China, paving the way for the country’s domestic players in 2024.

Counterpoint’s Tarun Pathak mentioned 2024 as a year of recovery and normalization after a difficult 2023.

Global smartphone sales grew 4% in 2024 after two consecutive years of annual declines, Counterpoint cites preliminary data. Smartphone sales marked a decade low in 2023.

Also Read: Nvidia, Broadcom Among Goldman Highlights For AI Opportunities

Almost every market grew, led by Europe, China, and Latin America.

The iPhone captured an 18% market share in 2024, down from 19% in 2023.

However, Apple continued to grow in its non-core markets, like Latin America, Africa, and Asia-Pacific. Needham’s Laura Martin expects iPhones to account for 89%-96% of Apple’s fiscal 2025 revenue.

Counterpoint’s Ivan Lam flagged a consumer pivot to Apple’s premium offering, helping to offset some of the declines. Lam pointed to the growing sell-through share of Pro series devices in markets like China.

Samsung Electronics Co (OTC:SSNLF) led with a market share of 19% in 2024, down from 20% in 2023, backed by demand for its S24 series and A-series product lines. The S24 series gained traction as the first phone positioned as an AI device and performed exceptionally in Western Europe and the USA.

Xiaomi (OTC:XIACF) (OTC:XIACY) reported a 14% market share in 2024, up from 13% a year ago. Oppo and Vivo each captured an 8% market share in 2024.

Xiaomi grew fastest among the top five brands in 2024, backed by its premiumization and expansion activities.

Oppo ended the year with stronger momentum. Vivo emerged amongst the top five, led by strong performance in India and China.

The top five remained the same as in 2023 but lost some share to Huawei Technologies, Honor, and Motorola. Huawei has no plans to give any respite to its rivals, who are doling out discounts for the New Year on their premium models.

China targets expanding government-supported consumption subsidies to include smartphones and other electronics, which will likely benefit domestic brands like Huawei and Xiaomi.

While generative AI-capable smartphones remain limited to the premium segment, Counterpoint expects them to become a norm for mid-range devices. By 2028, Counterpoint expects nine out of ten smartphones priced above $250 to be Generative AI-capable.

In 2025, Counterpoint expects revenue growth to continue to outpace volume growth, with revenues growing 8%, compared to 4%.

Story Continues

Price Action: AAPL stock is down 0.54% at $230.83 at the last check on Monday.

Also Read:

Apple does, however, find expansion in areas such Asia, Africa, and Latin America.

predictions.headline: Broadcom's AI Boom: Citi Sets $220 Target as Revenue and Dividends Soar
predictions.content:
Broadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO) just dropped the kind of news that makes investors sit up and take notice. While U.S. export restrictions on AI chips to China might rattle others, Broadcom is shrugging it off. Citi analysts note potential risks tied to Bytedance, a key customer projected to bring in $2$3 billion in 2025 sales. But here's the kicker: AI-heavyweights like Google (GOOGL) and Meta (NASDAQ:META) are set to pump $10 billion into Broadcom's ASIC sales next year. Throw in booming demand from new powerhouses like OpenAI and Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), and you've got a recipe for growth that dwarfs any headwinds.

High Yield Dividend Stocks in Gurus' Portfolio This Powerful Chart Made Peter Lynch 29% A Year For 13 Years How to calculate the intrinsic value of a stock?

Let's talk numbers, because Broadcom's fiscal 2024 results are jaw-dropping. Revenue soared 44% to a record $51.6 billion, with AI leading the chargea staggering 220% jump in AI revenue to $12.2 billion. Its semiconductor and infrastructure software segments smashed expectations, delivering $30.1 billion and $21.5 billion, respectively. The cherry on top? An 11% quarterly dividend hike to $0.59 per share, marking the 14th consecutive annual increase. Oh, and the company's free cash flow? A whopping $19.4 billion, positioning Broadcom to keep rewarding investors while powering ahead.

Looking forward, Broadcom is brimming with confidence, forecasting a 22% revenue jump in Q1 FY25 to $14.6 billion. Citi remains bullish, slapping a Buy rating and a $220 price target on the stock. Broadcom isn't just riding the AI waveit's building the surfboard, the wave, and the entire beach. If you're looking for a leader in tech that knows how to navigate challenges and crush expectations, Broadcom's got your attention.

This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

While the article does mention potential risks tied to a key customer, the overall tone is bullish, with Citi analysts setting a $220 price target. Broadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO) just dropped the kind of news that makes investors sit up and take notice. While U.S. export restrictions on AI chips to China might rattle others, Broadcom is shrugging it off. Citi analysts note potential risks tied to Bytedance, a key customer projected to bring in $2$3 billion in 2025 sales. But here's the kicker: AI-heavyweights like Google (GOOGL) and Meta (NASDAQ:META) are set to pump $10 billion into Broadcom's ASIC sales next year. Throw in booming demand from new powerhouses like OpenAI and Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), and you've got a recipe for growth that dwarfs any headwinds.

High Yield Dividend Stocks in Gurus' Portfolio This Powerful Chart Made Peter Lynch 29% A Year For 13 Years How to calculate the intrinsic value of a stock?

Let's talk numbers, because Broadcom's fiscal 2024 results are jaw-dropping. Revenue soared 44% to a record $51.6 billion, with AI leading the chargea staggering 220% jump in AI revenue to $12.2 billion. Its semiconductor and infrastructure software segments smashed expectations, delivering $30.1 billion and $21.5 billion, respectively. The cherry on top? An 11% quarterly dividend hike to $0.59 per share, marking the 14th consecutive annual increase. Oh, and the company's free cash flow? A whopping $19.4 billion, positioning Broadcom to keep rewarding investors while powering ahead.

Looking forward, Broadcom is brimming with confidence, forecasting a 22% revenue jump in Q1 FY25 to $14.6 billion. Citi remains bullish, slapping a Buy rating and a $220 price target on the stock. Broadcom isn't just riding the AI waveit's building the surfboard, the wave, and the entire beach. If you're looking for a leader in tech that knows how to navigate challenges and crush expectations, Broadcom's got your attention.

This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

View Comments
predictions.reasoning: The news article discusses Broadcom's impressive fiscal 2024 results, with a 44% revenue increase and a 220% jump in AI revenue. Although the article is about Broadcom, it mentions Apple as one of the companies driving demand for Broadcom's products, particularly in the AI sector. This indirect mention could have a positive impact on Apple's stock price. Considering the positive sentiment and growth prospects, as well as the potential indirect benefits to Apple, the probability of Apple's stock price rising due to this news is higher than the probability of it falling. However, the impact on Apple is indirect, and the article's primary focus is on Broadcom's performance, which means the effect on Apple's stock might be limited.

predictions.headline: Apple Falls to Second Place Globally as Samsung's S24 Dominates Smartphone Market
predictions.content:
Following Samsung (SSNLF), Counterpoint Research notes Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) now ranks second in worldwide smartphone market share for 2024. Apple commands a 18%, down from 19% last year; Samsung keeps 19%, a little decline from 20% in 2023

.With the popular A-series portfolio and significant demand for its AI-oriented S24 series, Samsung maintains leadership. In Europe and the United States, the S24 series excels especially, reinforcing Samsung's position.Apple's iPhone 16 series gets mixed reviews, mainly related to Apple Intelligence feature delays. Apple does, however, find expansion in areas such Asia, Africa, and Latin America.

Demand for the Pro and Pro Max variants keeps rising in China; Q4 2024 sales might even reach 50%.Reversing a decade-low in 2023, global smartphone sales climb 4% in 2024. Globally, consumer sentiment is improving; in Europe, China, and Latin America especially, it is showing a healthy improvement.

Apple is providing discounts on iPhone 16 models in China in order to keep its hold in a very cutthroat market while challenging Huawei.

This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

View Comments
predictions.reasoning: The news indicates that Apple has fallen to second place in global smartphone market share, which could negatively impact investor sentiment. The decline from 19% to 18% market share, coupled with mixed reviews for the iPhone 16 series, suggests potential challenges for Apple. However, there are positive aspects such as rising demand for Pro models in China and expansion in emerging markets. The overall sentiment is mixed, but the loss of market share and product issues weigh more heavily, leading to a higher probability of stock price decline. Considering the previous predictions and the mixed signals, I estimate a probability of 0.4 for a price rise and 0.6 for a price fall.

predictions.headline: Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint
predictions.content:
Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint

Smartphone giantApple Inc’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhones, minus their highly anticipated Apple Intelligence features, failed to gain traction in China, paving the way for the country’s domestic players in 2024.

Counterpoint’s Tarun Pathak mentioned 2024 as a year of recovery and normalization after a difficult 2023.

Global smartphone sales grew 4% in 2024 after two consecutive years of annual declines, Counterpoint cites preliminary data. Smartphone sales marked a decade low in 2023.

Also Read: Nvidia, Broadcom Among Goldman Highlights For AI Opportunities

Almost every market grew, led by Europe, China, and Latin America.

The iPhone captured an 18% market share in 2024, down from 19% in 2023.

However, Apple continued to grow in its non-core markets, like Latin America, Africa, and Asia-Pacific. Needham’s Laura Martin expects iPhones to account for 89%-96% of Apple’s fiscal 2025 revenue.

Counterpoint’s Ivan Lam flagged a consumer pivot to Apple’s premium offering, helping to offset some of the declines. Lam pointed to the growing sell-through share of Pro series devices in markets like China.

Samsung Electronics Co (OTC:SSNLF) led with a market share of 19% in 2024, down from 20% in 2023, backed by demand for its S24 series and A-series product lines. The S24 series gained traction as the first phone positioned as an AI device and performed exceptionally in Western Europe and the USA.

Xiaomi (OTC:XIACF) (OTC:XIACY) reported a 14% market share in 2024, up from 13% a year ago. Oppo and Vivo each captured an 8% market share in 2024.

Xiaomi grew fastest among the top five brands in 2024, backed by its premiumization and expansion activities.

Oppo ended the year with stronger momentum. Vivo emerged amongst the top five, led by strong performance in India and China.

The top five remained the same as in 2023 but lost some share to Huawei Technologies, Honor, and Motorola. Huawei has no plans to give any respite to its rivals, who are doling out discounts for the New Year on their premium models.

China targets expanding government-supported consumption subsidies to include smartphones and other electronics, which will likely benefit domestic brands like Huawei and Xiaomi.

While generative AI-capable smartphones remain limited to the premium segment, Counterpoint expects them to become a norm for mid-range devices. By 2028, Counterpoint expects nine out of ten smartphones priced above $250 to be Generative AI-capable.

In 2025, Counterpoint expects revenue growth to continue to outpace volume growth, with revenues growing 8%, compared to 4%.

Story Continues

Price Action: AAPL stock is down 0.54% at $230.83 at the last check on Monday.

Also Read:

Nvidia’s AI Leadership Shines While ON Semiconductor Faces Demand Slump: Analyst

Photo courtesy: Apple

predictions.headline: Broadcom's AI Boom: Citi Sets $220 Target as Revenue and Dividends Soar
predictions.content:
Broadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO) just dropped the kind of news that makes investors sit up and take notice. While U.S. export restrictions on AI chips to China might rattle others, Broadcom is shrugging it off. Citi analysts note potential risks tied to Bytedance, a key customer projected to bring in $2$3 billion in 2025 sales. But here's the kicker: AI-heavyweights like Google (GOOGL) and Meta (NASDAQ:META) are set to pump $10 billion into Broadcom's ASIC sales next year. Throw in booming demand from new powerhouses like OpenAI and Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), and you've got a recipe for growth that dwarfs any headwinds.

High Yield Dividend Stocks in Gurus' Portfolio This Powerful Chart Made Peter Lynch 29% A Year For 13 Years How to calculate the intrinsic value of a stock?

Let's talk numbers, because Broadcom's fiscal 2024 results are jaw-dropping. Revenue soared 44% to a record $51.6 billion, with AI leading the chargea staggering 220% jump in AI revenue to $12.2 billion. Its semiconductor and infrastructure software segments smashed expectations, delivering $30.1 billion and $21.5 billion, respectively. The cherry on top? An 11% quarterly dividend hike to $0.59 per share, marking the 14th consecutive annual increase. Oh, and the company's free cash flow? A whopping $19.4 billion, positioning Broadcom to keep rewarding investors while powering ahead.

Looking forward, Broadcom is brimming with confidence, forecasting a 22% revenue jump in Q1 FY25 to $14.6 billion. Citi remains bullish, slapping a Buy rating and a $220 price target on the stock. Broadcom isn't just riding the AI waveit's building the surfboard, the wave, and the entire beach. If you're looking for a leader in tech that knows how to navigate challenges and crush expectations, Broadcom's got your attention.

predictions.headline: Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint
predictions.content:
Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint

Smartphone giantApple Inc’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhones, minus their highly anticipated Apple Intelligence features, failed to gain traction in China, paving the way for the country’s domestic players in 2024.

Counterpoint’s Tarun Pathak mentioned 2024 as a year of recovery and normalization after a difficult 2023.

Global smartphone sales grew 4% in 2024 after two consecutive years of annual declines, Counterpoint cites preliminary data. Smartphone sales marked a decade low in 2023.

Also Read: Nvidia, Broadcom Among Goldman Highlights For AI Opportunities

Almost every market grew, led by Europe, China, and Latin America.

The iPhone captured an 18% market share in 2024, down from 19% in 2023.

However, Apple continued to grow in its non-core markets, like Latin America, Africa, and Asia-Pacific. Needham’s Laura Martin expects iPhones to account for 89%-96% of Apple’s fiscal 2025 revenue.

Counterpoint’s Ivan Lam flagged a consumer pivot to Apple’s premium offering, helping to offset some of the declines. Lam pointed to the growing sell-through share of Pro series devices in markets like China.

Samsung Electronics Co (OTC:SSNLF) led with a market share of 19% in 2024, down from 20% in 2023, backed by demand for its S24 series and A-series product lines. The S24 series gained traction as the first phone positioned as an AI device and performed exceptionally in Western Europe and the USA.

Xiaomi (OTC:XIACF) (OTC:XIACY) reported a 14% market share in 2024, up from 13% a year ago. Oppo and Vivo each captured an 8% market share in 2024.

Xiaomi grew fastest among the top five brands in 2024, backed by its premiumization and expansion activities.

Oppo ended the year with stronger momentum. Vivo emerged amongst the top five, led by strong performance in India and China.

The top five remained the same as in 2023 but lost some share to Huawei Technologies, Honor, and Motorola. Huawei has no plans to give any respite to its rivals, who are doling out discounts for the New Year on their premium models.

China targets expanding government-supported consumption subsidies to include smartphones and other electronics, which will likely benefit domestic brands like Huawei and Xiaomi.

While generative AI-capable smartphones remain limited to the premium segment, Counterpoint expects them to become a norm for mid-range devices. By 2028, Counterpoint expects nine out of ten smartphones priced above $250 to be Generative AI-capable.

In 2025, Counterpoint expects revenue growth to continue to outpace volume growth, with revenues growing 8%, compared to 4%.

Story Continues

Price Action: AAPL stock is down 0.54% at $230.83 at the last check on Monday.

Also Read:

Nvidia’s AI Leadership Shines While ON Semiconductor Faces Demand Slump: Analyst

predictions.headline: Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint
predictions.content:
Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint

Smartphone giantApple Inc’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhones, minus their highly anticipated Apple Intelligence features, failed to gain traction in China, paving the way for the country’s domestic players in 2024.

Counterpoint’s Tarun Pathak mentioned 2024 as a year of recovery and normalization after a difficult 2023.

Global smartphone sales grew 4% in 2024 after two consecutive years of annual declines, Counterpoint cites preliminary data. Smartphone sales marked a decade low in 2023.

Also Read: Nvidia, Broadcom Among Goldman Highlights For AI Opportunities

Almost every market grew, led by Europe, China, and Latin America.

The iPhone captured an 18% market share in 2024, down from 19% in 2023.

However, Apple continued to grow in its non-core markets, like Latin America, Africa, and Asia-Pacific. Needham’s Laura Martin expects iPhones to account for 89%-96% of Apple’s fiscal 2025 revenue.

Counterpoint’s Ivan Lam flagged a consumer pivot to Apple’s premium offering, helping to offset some of the declines. Lam pointed to the growing sell-through share of Pro series devices in markets like China.

Samsung Electronics Co (OTC:SSNLF) led with a market share of 19% in 2024, down from 20% in 2023, backed by demand for its S24 series and A-series product lines. The S24 series gained traction as the first phone positioned as an AI device and performed exceptionally in Western Europe and the USA.

Xiaomi (OTC:XIACF) (OTC:XIACY) reported a 14% market share in 2024, up from 13% a year ago. Oppo and Vivo each captured an 8% market share in 2024.

Xiaomi grew fastest among the top five brands in 2024, backed by its premiumization and expansion activities.

Oppo ended the year with stronger momentum. Vivo emerged amongst the top five, led by strong performance in India and China.

The top five remained the same as in 2023 but lost some share to Huawei Technologies, Honor, and Motorola. Huawei has no plans to give any respite to its rivals, who are doling out discounts for the New Year on their premium models.

China targets expanding government-supported consumption subsidies to include smartphones and other electronics, which will likely benefit domestic brands like Huawei and Xiaomi.

While generative AI-capable smartphones remain limited to the premium segment, Counterpoint expects them to become a norm for mid-range devices. By 2028, Counterpoint expects nine out of ten smartphones priced above $250 to be Generative AI-capable.

In 2025, Counterpoint expects revenue growth to continue to outpace volume growth, with revenues growing 8%, compared to 4%.

Story Continues

Price Action: AAPL stock is down 0.54% at $230.83 at the last check on Monday.

predictions.headline: Broadcom's AI Boom: Citi Sets $220 Target as Revenue and Dividends Soar
predictions.content:
Broadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO) just dropped the kind of news that makes investors sit up and take notice. While U.S. export restrictions on AI chips to China might rattle others, Broadcom is shrugging it off. Citi analysts note potential risks tied to Bytedance, a key customer projected to bring in $2$3 billion in 2025 sales. But here's the kicker: AI-heavyweights like Google (GOOGL) and Meta (NASDAQ:META) are set to pump $10 billion into Broadcom's ASIC sales next year. Throw in booming demand from new powerhouses like OpenAI and Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), and you've got a recipe for growth that dwarfs any headwinds.

Let's talk numbers, because Broadcom's fiscal 2024 results are jaw-dropping. Revenue soared 44% to a record $51.6 billion, with AI leading the chargea staggering 220% jump in AI revenue to $12.2 billion. Its semiconductor and infrastructure software segments smashed expectations, delivering $30.1 billion and $21.5 billion, respectively. The cherry on top? An 11% quarterly dividend hike to $0.59 per share, marking the 14th consecutive annual increase. Oh, and the company's free cash flow? A whopping $19.4 billion, positioning Broadcom to keep rewarding investors while powering ahead.

Looking forward, Broadcom is brimming with confidence, forecasting a 22% revenue jump in Q1 FY25 to $14.6 billion. Citi remains bullish, slapping a Buy rating and a $220 price target on the stock. Broadcom isn't just riding the AI waveit's building the surfboard, the wave, and the entire beach. If you're looking for a leader in tech that knows how to navigate challenges and crush expectations, Broadcom's got your attention.

predictions.headline: Broadcom's AI Boom: Citi Sets $220 Target as Revenue and Dividends Soar
predictions.content:
Broadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO) just dropped the kind of news that makes investors sit up and take notice. While U.S. export restrictions on AI chips to China might rattle others, Broadcom is shrugging it off. Citi analysts note potential risks tied to Bytedance, a key customer projected to bring in $2$3 billion in 2025 sales. But here's the kicker: AI-heavyweights like Google (GOOGL) and Meta (NASDAQ:META) are set to pump $10 billion into Broadcom's ASIC sales next year. Throw in booming demand from new powerhouses like OpenAI and Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), and you've got a recipe for growth that dwarfs any headwinds.

High Yield Dividend Stocks in Gurus' Portfolio This Powerful Chart Made Peter Lynch 29% A Year For 13 Years How to calculate the intrinsic value of a stock?

Let's talk numbers, because Broadcom's fiscal 2024 results are jaw-dropping. Revenue soared 44% to a record $51.6 billion, with AI leading the chargea staggering 220% jump in AI revenue to $12.2 billion. Its semiconductor and infrastructure software segments smashed expectations, delivering $30.1 billion and $21.5 billion, respectively. The cherry on top? An 11% quarterly dividend hike to $0.59 per share, marking the 14th consecutive annual increase. Oh, and the company's free cash flow? A whopping $19.4 billion, positioning Broadcom to keep rewarding investors while powering ahead.

Looking forward, Broadcom is brimming with confidence, forecasting a 22% revenue jump in Q1 FY25 to $14.6 billion. Citi remains bullish, slapping a Buy rating and a $220 price target on the stock. Broadcom isn't just riding the AI waveit's building the surfboard, the wave, and the entire beach. If you're looking for a leader in tech that knows how to navigate challenges and crush expectations, Broadcom's got your attention.

This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

predictions.headline: Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint
predictions.content:
Apple's iPhone Market Share Declines in China, Huawei and Xiaomi Gain Momentum in 2024: Counterpoint

Smartphone giantApple Inc’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhones, minus their highly anticipated Apple Intelligence features, failed to gain traction in China, paving the way for the country’s domestic players in 2024.

Counterpoint’s Tarun Pathak mentioned 2024 as a year of recovery and normalization after a difficult 2023.

Global smartphone sales grew 4% in 2024 after two consecutive years of annual declines, Counterpoint cites preliminary data. Smartphone sales marked a decade low in 2023.

Also Read: Nvidia, Broadcom Among Goldman Highlights For AI Opportunities

Almost every market grew, led by Europe, China, and Latin America.

The iPhone captured an 18% market share in 2024, down from 19% in 2023.

However, Apple continued to grow in its non-core markets, like Latin America, Africa, and Asia-Pacific. Needham’s Laura Martin expects iPhones to account for 89%-96% of Apple’s fiscal 2025 revenue.

Counterpoint’s Ivan Lam flagged a consumer pivot to Apple’s premium offering, helping to offset some of the declines. Lam pointed to the growing sell-through share of Pro series devices in markets like China.

Samsung Electronics Co (OTC:SSNLF) led with a market share of 19% in 2024, down from 20% in 2023, backed by demand for its S24 series and A-series product lines. The S24 series gained traction as the first phone positioned as an AI device and performed exceptionally in Western Europe and the USA.

Xiaomi (OTC:XIACF) (OTC:XIACY) reported a 14% market share in 2024, up from 13% a year ago. Oppo and Vivo each captured an 8% market share in 2024.

Xiaomi grew fastest among the top five brands in 2024, backed by its premiumization and expansion activities.

Oppo ended the year with stronger momentum. Vivo emerged amongst the top five, led by strong performance in India and China.

The top five remained the same as in 2023 but lost some share to Huawei Technologies, Honor, and Motorola. Huawei has no plans to give any respite to its rivals, who are doling out discounts for the New Year on their premium models.

China targets expanding government-supported consumption subsidies to include smartphones and other electronics, which will likely benefit domestic brands like Huawei and Xiaomi.

While generative AI-capable smartphones remain limited to the premium segment, Counterpoint expects them to become a norm for mid-range devices. By 2028, Counterpoint expects nine out of ten smartphones priced above $250 to be Generative AI-capable.

In 2025, Counterpoint expects revenue growth to continue to outpace volume growth, with revenues growing 8%, compared to 4%.

Story Continues

Price Action: AAPL stock is down 0.54% at $230.83 at the last check on Monday.

predictions.headline: Broadcom's AI Boom: Citi Sets $220 Target as Revenue and Dividends Soar
predictions.content:

But here's the kicker: AI-heavyweights like Google (GOOGL) and Meta (NASDAQ:META) are set to pump $10 billion into Broadcom's ASIC sales next year. Throw in booming demand from new powerhouses like OpenAI and Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), and you've got a recipe for growth that dwarfs any headwinds.
